Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative research: Unraveling the post-Pliocene Arctic Ocean transition to the icehouse climate
Award.AbstractNarration: Funds are provided to allow the PIs to develop a continuous record of changes in the Arctic Ocean in response to climatic cooling and growth of ice sheets in the Early to Middle Pleistocene based on sediment cores from the western Arctic Ocean. They will utilize a suite of proxies (microfaunal assemblages, stable and radiogenic isotopes, biomarkers, sediment mineralogy and elemental composition and grain size) to reconstruct variations in glacial inputs, sea ice, and water circulation. The use of paleobiological and geochemical proxies will be greatly enhanced by a unique sediment core that has a rich calcareous microfossil record extending through most of the Quaternary and potentially into the Pliocene, unlike other cores from the Arctic Ocean. This is a unique find that they can capitalize on as Arctic cores typically preserve calcareous microfossils only in Late Quaternary sediments. Age control will be achieved by paleomagnetic, 10Be, Sr-isotope, and cyclostratigraphic methods. This research will allow them to test whether there was an overall progressive growth in ice sheets and sea-ice cover and if sea ice and continental glaciers changed synchronously. They will also test whether the Mid Pleistocene Transition led to the growth of a super-thick Laurentide Ice Sheet by analyzing changes in glacial inputs from the northern Laurentide margin, with a multi-century scale record for the threshold glaciation ca. 650 ka, which initiated the icehouse world.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The intellectual merit of this project was to develop a continuous record of changes in the Arctic Ocean in response to climatic cooling and growth of ice sheets in the Early to Middle Pleistocene based on sediment cores from the western Arctic Ocean. As his contribution to the project, Dr. Joseph Ortiz of the Department of Geology at Kent State University has developed a methodology to determine the age of Arctic sediment by astronomical tuning. This is a difficult task in many cases because traditional means of determining age in marine cores requires the presence of fossil calcium carbonate hard parts from marine microorganisms. Conditions in the Arctic however, often cause these microfossils to dissolve away. Other methods that can be used for dating Arctic sediment include paleomagnetic analysis, however these methods can produce ambiguous results in the Arctic because the measurement are take so close to the north pole, or as a result of changes in bottom water oxygen content, which can overprint the paleomagnetic signal.

As an alternative, Dr. Ortiz developed a way to quickly and reliably measure the mineralogy of the sediment using an safe, inexpensive optically-based method. Measurements from sediment cores can be measured rapidly. The resulting data is then analyzed using time-series analysis methods to extract cycle signals from the downcore measurements that relate to changes in mineralogy a know periodicities influenced by astronomical changes in the Earth Orbit. These data can then be compared with know estimates of the changes the eccentricity of the Earth’s orbit through time to assign ages to sediment from different depths within the sediment cores. The method was applied to cores from different location and compared with independent age estimates to evaluate the uncertainties in the results.

The broader impact of the method was to enable evaluation of sediment age over a wider range of depositional environments in the Arctic than was previously possible. This has academic applications by improving our understanding of the history of climate change and the evolution of the Arctic as a system, but may also have applied implications to aid in determining the age of artic resources associated with specific formations or as an aid toward core to seismic integration.
